pros: Great work life balance generous vacation nice people
cons: pays are a bit less than market average

review_title: Senior Management has their head in the sand
pros: Pros are dwindling every day….but the people remain the best aspect.
cons: Senior management doesn’t seem to understand that the job market has changed, and more and more employers are offering full time WFH positions. CEO took a 3 month leave of absence to Australia, but claims to relate to the issues us everyday people have to face. Benefits have been cut. Cost of living increase is a joke. What used to be a fair and enjoyable workplace now feels authoritarian, depressing and unstable. New blood is desperately needed.

pros: Great time off and benefits plan.
cons: Compensation could be a lot better. Salary increases are minimal.

review_title: Good and reliable organization to work for
pros: - Opportunity to learn - Very supportive team - Reliable income - Good benefits
cons: - Opportunity to progress career wise is very slow

review_title: Good for short term, not a place to build a long term career
pros: The vacation and sick day allotment is extremely generous. The work day is flexible, although that is dependent on your team. People are genuinely nice.
cons: CIHI lacks a vision for the future. The CEO and upper management is stuck in a 1990s mentality when times have changed. This is reflected in the quality of work. It's difficult to "move up". Most career moves will be lateral rather than vertical, it's very difficult to gain a promotion. Despite the difficultly in being promoted, middle management is extremely bloated. While committed to diversity, upper management is extremely white.

pros:
Did a good job when Covid hit, kept people updated, communicated and put employee safety first
Good pension plan
Smart colleagues
Work that matters and impacts Canadians
People care about our mandate 
Christmas office closure
Ample time off extended to employees for appointments (medical, school, bank etc)
cons:
The RTO has been stressful on a lot of employees and they’re leaving in droves 
HR is incompetent, the department isn’t well respected internally at all for many reasons
Change can be slow/difficult 
Very hard to move around or get promoted. (I applied for a lateral move internally and didn’t get contacted AT ALL, despite meeting all of the qualification criteria) 
Compulsory to go into the office on a weekly basis, not moving with the times. 
ITS had a Town hall to address employee concerns (namely the significant portion of people leaving), it left more people annoyed than anything. 
Hard to get courses paid for even though it’s listed as a benefit
A lot of great people have walked away and a lot of who are left are looking externally
Micro management mentality

review_title: Used to be a very good company, but not anymore
pros: Good working people Good benefit package Work life balance if you don't have a horrible manager that expects you to work for free.
cons: Management team favor hard workers but excellent . Very political world. Promotion, raise and bonus are predetermined, and not based on your performance

pros:
- Work-life balance
- Allocated money for training and learning opportunities ( you have to plan for it and go after it, but you will certainly get it )
- You have a career for the next 30 years if you go with the flow
- Highly educated staff ( in various fields )
- Interesting projects ( if you are interested in moving healthcare forward, you have access to the data here and definitely have an edge )
- If you are interested in developing policies to move healthcare forward, you definitely have an edge here.
- You will not experience data access restrictions ( which usually is a very common challenge when it comes to solving any problem with the data ).
cons:
- If you are young, passionate, and have a go-getter attitude, you are in the minority and definitely can experience a lot of pushbacks.
- Lots of regulations, policies, and privacy concerns for everything ( but, if you are a go-getter you can try to update those policies and hopefully get them buy-in, you still get the pushbacks and you might get fired for trying this, but do not give up your hope, knock until someone opens the door ).

job_title: Applications Development Senior Analyst in Ottawa, ON
pros: Great people and good environment
cons: Lack of vision from management

pros: great working environment, good teams
cons: salary lower than other companies

review_title: Was a good company. Senior management treats employees like children.
pros:
Great colleagues.
Meaningful work.
Great middle management.
cons:
Very top down management heavy. Sends out employee surveys and cherry-pick results (eg. 25% of you agree with this so we are going to go with that). Treat employees like children as if we don't work in data analytics.

Benefits has been stripped from what it was before while again, cherry-pick information to pretend it's better rather than be straight up and frank about it.

RTO management was a disaster.

Lots of young and experienced talents leaving due to poor recent directions. Their solution is to set up recruitment booths at universities for people freshly out of school.

review_title: Great place to work, but needs to adapt to 2022
pros: Smart and kind colleagues, important work, above average compensation, excellent benefits and work-life balance. People are generally respectful and collaborative, and employees are recognised for their contributions.
cons: Needlessly bureaucratic - very attached to processes and it takes a long time for new hires to learn to navigate all the forms and steps required to get anything done. HR handled RTO quite poorly, as is evident from other reviews.

pros:
I had the opportunity to work in different divisions and branches of CIHI. While some teams are intense but amazing others are stagnant, political and assembly-line sort of work processes. Some managers are heavily invested in their team’s professional development, there are pockets of skeptics who would hinder your development in order to retain staff. 

There is a diversity and inclusion focus but hardly any representation in senior leadership. 

The organization is not very well known outside of its limited network of nonprofit, health and data industries. 

Directors are like VPs and Managers Directors. The C-Suite is professional and approachable. 

If you are considering a career at CIHI, think about the career trajectory you’re aiming for the next few years. If you’re hired on a contract basis, please know it’s very hard to train new people. You will eventually get hired on a permanent basis. There are many people who got their foot in the door and moved to several prolific positions within the organization.
cons: I’ve combined pros and cons.

job_title: Software Developer in North York, ON
pros: defined benefit pension, friendly staff, good work-life balance, great office location off york mills station, benefits start day 1
cons: tech stack a bit dated, strict privacy and security regulations (no to the wfh nomad life)

pros: Work life balance is great with amazing benefits package!
cons: Difficult to advance your career

pros: Mostly respectful employer with good benefit package
cons: Difficult to move up the ladder with no system of promotion. Also, employee rating system is primitive and doesn't reflect the effort of the employee (their scale is 1 to 4 and everyone gets a 3!). On a different note, I faced ignorant racism from colleagues at my workplace.

pros: Great work life balance, people, culture. Opportunities given to learn new things. Great pension plan
cons: Can be slow paced at times.

pros: Interesting work, meaningful mandate, good work life balance
cons: All organizations have pros and cons.

pros: CIHI is a great place to work as it prioritizes employee well-being and a sense of purpose. Great opportunity for you to move around the company and experience various experiences to progress your career.
cons: Churn due to lack of growth opportunities.

pros: It was a great place to work and the people were awesome. The people I worked with made it a joy to come to work every day.

review_title: this is a great place to work

pros: Great company culture and a work life balance.
cons: Due to the nature of work sometimes slow to innovate.

review_title: Friendly and hardworking staff, plagued by burecracy, politics and poor workload estimation.
pros: Benefits and location. Office is new and nice and good opportunities for nature walks during the work day. Friendly staff that are genuinly helpful and dilligent. Training opportunities are decent depending on which area you are in. Great for analytical and IT staff but quite poor and very limited for just about everyone else. Good place to work if you are looking for something stable and are not ambitious. Flexible work arrangements are possible depending on which area. Tends to be great for IT but poor for other program areas.
cons: Management are very ambitious but some are not good with workload estimation. (Projects often overrun and overtime by staff often put in. Despite overtime and hard work, recognition rarely given.) Promotions only possible if there is a vaccancy (regardless of how good performance is over the years). Performance reviews unfairly implemented (even in the same team, given by the same manager). Numerous known cases of favouritism. Politics at manager level and above quite toxic and political play affects levels below managers too. Large on burecracy which stunts work progress and speed. Bullying issues have known to be ignored by senior management and HR (even though they document them- they only pay lip service).

pros: accommodating, flexible, great benefits, remote options
cons: Parking not great for location

job_title: Java Developer in North York, ON
pros:
Nice work environment with friendly and helpful colleagues.
Meaningful work.
Well laid out processes and procedures.

review_title: Great place to start a career

cons: No pension plan anymore, some bureaucracy also nothing close to other government ministries, no clear career path past a certain point (people basically are waiting to the person above them moves on/retires)

pros: Very friendly and helpful colleagues to guide through processes. Managers focussed on job but never negelects professional growth and development of the team members. President himself has a very open mindset and friendly character.
cons: Vertical corporate ladder may be difficult to climb relative to larger corporations, since less opportunity to go up. Then again, I suppose there's less internal competition?
